bibRefCitation.author: Chapuis, F.
bibRefCitation.refString: Chapuis, F. 1865. Monographie des Platypodides. Dessain, Liege, Belgium.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Notes. This commonly collected
Tesserocerus species
ranges from Mexico to Argentina and is recorded from almost all Neotropical countries, including Peru . Older identifications are often given as
Tesserocerus dejeani Chapuis
, a junior synonym. However, many South American specimens labeled
T. dewalquei
or
T. dejeani
belong to an overlooked smaller, undescribed species which seems to be widespread in Amazonia, my
Tesserocerus LRK
013. The Peru specimens I have seen are all LRK 013; none are
T. dewalquei .
The species is tentatively listed here as it is recorded from Peru ( Schedl 1972 ; Wood and Bright 1992); it may well be present in Peru , since there are syntypes of
T. dejeani
from Colombia (IRSNB).
Tesserocerus elegans Chapuis, 1865

Notes.
Not represented in the material at hand. Nunberg (1939) reported two females from “ Peru ” (no other data). As females are difficult to separate and it is not known what material was available to Nunberg , this country record should be verified. However , the species has been found in Colombia and Venezuela , so it is likely that it occurs in Peru as well
.

caption.paragraph: Table 1. Previous country records for described species identified in this study or those recorded previously from Peru ( Schedl 1972 ; Wood and Bright 1992). * = first record for Peru; ** = first record for South America; Boldface = new country records from Atkinson (2016) .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Notes.
Found throughout Mexico and Central America , but only known from Brazil in South America. One additional male: Junín , 15 km NW from Satipo , Rio Venado village environs,
1,300 m
, window trap , −11.2811°, −74.7686°,
3.X.2015
A. Petrov ( AVPC )
.

Notes.
Previously known only from two specimens from Brazil . A Peru series was col- lected from Los Amigos Biological Station ( eight from FIT and Malaise traps ). An additional female is labeled Madre de Dios , Puerto Maldonado ,
5-XII- 2013
, 267 m, −12.5610°, −71.1065°, T. Pérez , Malaise trap ( FSCA )
.

bibRefCitation.author: Chapuis, F.
bibRefCitation.refString: Chapuis, F. 1865. Monographie des Platypodides. Dessain, Liege, Belgium.

subSubSection.paragraph: Notes. Only known from South America, where it is widespread.

Tesserocerus inermis Guérin-Méneville, 1838
Notes.
Only known from South America, where it is widespread. Material in the current study is from 260–560 m elevation, from FIT and Malaise traps.

paragraph.materialsCitation: Previously known from northern South America and Peru and Bolivia . New Peru records: 1 male , Pasco , [Oxapampa,]

caption.paragraph: Table 2. Number of specimens per described species and unidentified morphospecies collected mainly by flight-intercept (FIT) and Malaise trapping by R. Leschen (in 1993) and the Chaboo project (in 2010 and 2011). * = a described species not previously recorded from Peru; ** = a described species new to South America.

tableNote.paragraph: San Jacinto: −2.3125°, −75.8628°, 175 m, FIT, 3–12 Jul. 1993, R Leschen.
Teniente López: −2.5943°, −76.1153°, 230 m, FIT, 18–26 Jul. 1993, R Leschen.

Los Amigos Biol. Station: Tambopata, Caroline Chaboo project. Most specimens were collected from an FIT or a Malaise trap, both at coordinates −12.5521°, −70.1096° and 295 m elevation, both run 9–15 July 2010 and 7–13 June 2011. Twelve specimens were taken from a Malaise trap at −12.5694°, −70.1010°, 260 m elevation, run by Maria Endera for various intervals between 29 July and 23 Sept. 2010; a UV light was run at the same site during two nights in 2010 and one night in 2011 by Chaboo and co-workers (17 specimens, 6 species). Finally, 10 individuals (4 genera, 6 species) were collected at −12.5660°, −70.102 0, 280 m elevation, 8 June 2011 by Caroline Chaboo from
Heliconia
leaf rolls.

A smaller, undescribed species is sometimes identified as
T. spinax
, but it has not been found in Peru .

Notes.
This undescribed species is smaller than, but very similar to,
T. ericius
. It is common in Costa Rica . I have seen three specimens from Bolivia ( USNM , FSCA ), so its occurrence in Peru ( Table 2 ) is not surprising
.
